title: how to update - Windows 10
body:
Hi,
I don't quite understand how to update: I downloaded the "scrcpy-win64-v1.14.zip" file... Now I just replace the content of the previous version's folder? 
Excuse me for the dumb question (and yes, this is a question, not a bug report: I don't know how to label it)

Thank you
author: piloro

comments.body:
> Now I just replace the content of the previous version's folder?

Yes.

In general, just remove the old folder and extract the new one (old files may have been deleted in a newer release).
thank you.

title: Question: what version of ADB is needed for 1.14?
body:
Sorry to post a bug report when it's actually a question. I couldn't find where I could post a question. :)

In 1.14 you say:

> Upgrade platform-tools to 30.0.0 (adb) in Windows releases

Will I be able to use Scrcpy 1.14 with an older version of ADB? Say version 1.0.36? Unfortunately I have a need to use that version of ADB.

If not, should I stay at my current version of Scrcpy which is 1.12 or can I upgrade to 1.13?
author: herrenP

comments.body:
> Will I be able to use Scrcpy 1.14 with an older version of ADB? Say version 1.0.36? Unfortunately I have a need to use that version of ADB.

Yes, you can use the version you want.

Just replace `adb.exe` in the scrcpy folder, or set the environement variable `ADB=C:\path\to\your\adb.exe`.
Thank you!

title: Drop dependency on Java/server
body: Is there any reason this can't just use the native `screenrecord` and `input` CLI tools?
author: luke-jr

comments.body:
For input:
 - performance #231

For video:
 - `screenrecord` is limited to 180 seconds
 - buffering issues with `adb shell` stdout (a frame could be written but stay in buffer)
 - reduced frame latency #646
 - correctly handle rotation
 - correctly handle resize without adding unwanted black borders (when one dimension is not multiple of 8)

For info, I used the output of `screenrecord` for the initial PoC, killing it and restarting it on every rotation and every 3 minutes (which by the way produced a corrupted stream), it worked but was very hacky.

title: execute multiple commands
body:
hi I want  to know that how can I execute multiple commands like
adb devices
scrcpy --no-control
scrcpy --bit-rate 6M
scrcpy --max-fps 40
scrcpy --max-size 1028

in given commands, it stops at bit rate and max fps and max size will not be executed please help me.
thanks. :)
author: sharukhkhanajm

comments.body: Try `scrcpy --no-control --bit-rate 6M --max-fps 40 --max-size 1028`?

this is my .bat file
cd c:\Mirror
adb devices
scrcpy --bit-rate 6M --max-size 1028

and when I run this file I get this output

C:\Mirror>scrcpy --bit-rate 6M --max-size 1028
scrcpy-server.jar: 1 file pushed. 0.6 MB/s (19342 bytes in 0.031s)
INFO: Initial texture: 496x1024

I think the last command is running and the bit rate is being ignored what do you think ?
No, it's not ignored. Try with `--bit-rate 1M`, you'll notice the difference in quality.

title: Specifying which device to connect to over TCP/IP
body:
Hi, I'm sorry if this isn't the right place for this. I read the instructions and they say that if you have more than one device under `adb devices` you have to specify the serial number of which device you want to connect to. But is there a way to specify which device you want to connect to over TCP/IP when you have multiple devices connected without using the serial number? Like just by specifying the IP address of the device or something like that? 

The reason I ask is because when devices are connected over USB the serial number is listed when you do `adb devices` (I'm pretty sure that's the serial number... right?) which makes it easy to then input as `scrcpy -s whateveryourserialnumberis` but when devices are connected over TCP/IP it just shows the IP. So you either have to have your serial number written down and saved somewhere or possibly run an adb command to get it (although I can't seem to get any to work). 

It's not a big deal for someone like me who is only ever really connecting to 2 devices, my phone and my tablet, but I'm interested in if there's a way to do this entirely within the command line rather than having to input the serial number from a saved file or a sticky note or something like that.
author: richbordoni

comments.body:
For example:

```
scrcpy -s 192.168.0.1:5555
```

(it works like `adb -s …`)

Huh, I could've sworn that I tried that! It looks like I forgot to add the port on the end of it and then I have no idea why I didn't just try it again with the port. Well, thanks anyway! Works perfectly. 

Might want to add that to the readme though?

Btw, thank you for developing scrcpy! It works extremely well and it's a million times faster and more reliable than what I was using before (TeamViewer).

> Might want to add that to the readme though?

1144f642144103a3b0bbd017998d75edd9d2a8b8 :+1:

> It works extremely well and it's a million times faster and more reliable

:tada:

title: can i use low compress rate codecs?
body:
like mpeg-2, h263
those codecs will work with lower cpu usages
author: djdisodo

comments.body: No, it only supports H.264 for now. But H.264 is typically both harware-encoded and decoded.
@rom1v do you have any plan to support other codecs?
Probably when there are hardware encoders and decoders for the current generation of codecs (AV1, HEVC).

title: how to listen on the change of the screen ?rotation
body:
(maybe i know  i look like  i am fool)
i am viewing your code ,i know the aidl listens the phone rotation,but how the pc knows phone is roating?
author: ShiverZm

comments.body:
> how the pc knows phone is roating

The PC doesn't know the device rotation.

When the device rotates, it just receives a frame having another dimension, so it resizes itself.

(Note that it would not be sufficient if we would need to draw a device around the video on the client side)

title: tarball verification problem
body:
tried to verify tarball via that signature gives that error:

```
$ gpg --verify SHA256SUMS.txt.asc v1.10.tar.gz
gpg: Signature made Sun 04 Aug 2019 07:24:18 PM +0430
gpg:                using RSA key C981F71CE7A09ED4A700181FBE1D62782B051E3F
gpg: Can't check signature: No public key
```

trying `gpg --receive-keys C981F71CE7A09ED4A700181FBE1D62782B051E3F` it says:

```
gpg: key 03F8A21687753EFF: public key "Romain Vimont <rom@rom1v.com>" imported
gpg: Total number processed: 1
gpg:               imported: 1
```

but after that trying to verify tarball yields another error:

```
$ gpg --verify SHA256SUMS.txt.asc v1.10.tar.gz
gpg: Signature made Sun 04 Aug 2019 07:24:18 PM +0430
gpg:                using RSA key C981F71CE7A09ED4A700181FBE1D62782B051E3F
gpg: BAD signature from "Romain Vimont <rom@rom1v.com>" [unknown]
```
author: faezebax

comments.body:
`SHA256SUMS.txt.asc` is the signature for `SHA256SUMS.txt`, which contains the SHA256 for the file released:
```
cbeb1a4e046f1392c1dc73c3ccffd7f86dec4636b505556ea20929687a119390  scrcpy-server-v1.10.jar
f98b400b3764404b33b212e9762dd6f1593ddb766c1480fc2609c94768e4a8e1  scrcpy-win32-v1.10.zip
95de34575d873c7e95dfcfb5e74d0f6af4f70b2a5bc6fde0f48d1a05480e3a44  scrcpy-win64-v1.10.zip
```

```
$ gpg --verify SHA256SUMS.txt.asc SHA256SUMS.txt
gpg: Signature made Sun Aug  4 16:54:18 2019 CEST
gpg:                using RSA key C981F71CE7A09ED4A700181FBE1D62782B051E3F
gpg: Good signature from "Romain Vimont <rom@rom1v.com>" [ultimate
```

The archive `v1.10.tar.gz` is generated on-the-fly (or cached) by GitHub. It is not signed.

However, the tag `v1.10` is the git repository is signed:

```
$ git verify-tag v1.10
gpg: Signature made Sun Aug  4 16:41:09 2019 CEST
gpg:                using RSA key C981F71CE7A09ED4A700181FBE1D62782B051E3F
gpg:                issuer "rom@rom1v.com"
gpg: Good signature from "Romain Vimont <rom@rom1v.com>" [ultimate]
```

title: How do I reduce bitrate for scrcpy wireless
body:
i try the code but it says scrcpy is not an internal or external command....

Could you please give me a solution step by step?
author: KxngLeoKaos

comments.body:
1. Open a console (`cmd.exe`)
2. Go to your scrcpy directory (`cd C:\path\of\scrcpy`)
3. Run `scrcpy -b 4M` (for a bitrate of 4M).

title: Trying to reduce my bitrate
body:
Im trying to input the command prompt to reduce bitrate but it keeps saying that its not an internal or external command 

Could you please take me step by step through the process

C:\Users\chrisana>scrcpy --bit-rate 2M
'scrcpy' is not recognized as internal or external command, operable program or batch file
author: KxngLeoKaos

comments.body:
You are on windows, you will need to specify the entire path

scrcpy --bit-rate 2M 

should be 

scrcpy.exe --bit-rate 2M

On Windows, you can call a command with or without an explicit `.exe`.

The problem is that you must call it from the scrcpy directory (`cd C:\path\to\scrcpy`), or add its directory in your `PATH`.

title: Creating a .bat File For Recording
body: Hello. I am interested in creating a Batch File to make scrcpy record a Video. What can I do?
author: ghost

comments.body:
In the scrcpy folder, just create a file named `something.bat` containing:

```
scrcpy --record file.mkv
```

scrcpy --record file.mkv --fullscreen

title: thankyou
body: How to remove the title bar, let me know which file to edit it, thank you
author: cutoseo

comments.body:
```diff
diff --git a/app/src/screen.c b/app/src/screen.c
index 18d24dd..34ba467 100644
--- a/app/src/screen.c
+++ b/app/src/screen.c
@@ -152,6 +152,8 @@ screen_init_rendering(struct screen *screen, const char *window_title,
 #endif
     }
 
+    window_flags |= SDL_WINDOW_BORDERLESS;
+
     screen->window = SDL_CreateWindow(window_title, SDL_WINDOWPOS_UNDEFINED,
                                       SDL_WINDOWPOS_UNDEFINED,
                                       window_size.width, window_size.height,
```

i want after removing the border it will look like in this image, still doing as you say, thank you
sorry for using google translate
If you apply the patch I just provided (just add the `SDL_WINDOW_BORDERLESS` flag), this is what you will get.

This class is just an unit test for the `ControlEventReader` class (which deserializes the events received from the client).

You can execute it with:
```
cd server
../gradlew test
```

title: WiGig 802.11ad/ay
body: Anyone's guess how this would perform latency wise on WiGig Devices?  Also can encoding be changed to support H265 (HEVC)?
author: creativeedge

comments.body:
> Also can encoding be changed to support H265 (HEVC)?

No.

Are there any Android device able to hardware-encode to H.265?

When AV1 or H.265 will be widely available in hardware encoding, yes, _scrcpy_ will need it.
Thanks rom1v.  How about WiGig - do you think that will kill latency when it is available?

> How about WiGig - do you think that will kill latency when it is available?

No idea.

Currently, the big problem with latency over wifi is packet loss for TCP (which blocks everything until the packet is resent). If your wifi is "ok" and you use a reasonable bitrate, the latency is not that high (`scrcpy -m800 -b2M`).
Thanks rom1v for everything.

title: Black screen - Nox
body:
Hello,

I'm desperately trying to make this nice little tool work with an Android emulator.

The best I could get is with Nox on Nougat. The result is that the screen is black. Why ? I get no error from the command line interface.
author: kensiko

comments.body: Oh, please note that the controls do work on this black screen.

> I'm desperately trying to make this nice little tool work with an Android emulator.

An emulator will probably not be able to use an hardware encoder to encode the video, so at best performance will be (very) bad. I don't know why it displays no content at all though.

I see.

I've tried multiple Android-x86 in the last hour without any success. And on my old Nexus 4 it works in 2 minutes.

We are thinking about just plugging a phone and let it ON all the time, accessing it with SCRCPY when required.

title: where is the homepage and Task button？
body: rightclik is back，but where is the homepage and Task button？
author: hentai87

comments.body:
| Action                                 |   Shortcut                    |
 | -------------------------------------- |:----------------------------  |
 | switch fullscreen mode                 | `Ctrl`+`f`                    |
 | resize window to 1:1 (pixel-perfect)   | `Ctrl`+`g`                    |
 | resize window to remove black borders  | `Ctrl`+`x` \| _Double-click¹_ |
 | click on `HOME`                        | `Ctrl`+`h` \| _Middle-click_  |
 | click on `BACK`                        | `Ctrl`+`b` \| _Right-click²_  |
 | click on `APP_SWITCH`                  | `Ctrl`+`s`                    |
 | click on `MENU`                        | `Ctrl`+`m`                    |
 | click on `VOLUME_UP`                   | `Ctrl`+`↑` _(up)_             |
 | click on `VOLUME_DOWN`                 | `Ctrl`+`↓` _(down)_           |
 | click on `POWER`                       | `Ctrl`+`p`                    |
 | turn screen on                         | _Right-click²_                |
 | paste computer clipboard to device     | `Ctrl`+`v`                    |
 | enable/disable FPS counter (on stdout) | `Ctrl`+`i`                    |
 | install APK from computer              | drag & drop APK file          |
 | push file to `/sdcard/`                | drag & drop non-APK file      |
cool
Also found in `scrcpy --help`

There has been an update and the shortcuts use left Alt/Super by default. Here is a complete list from Help (thanks @otsenreDC):

    --shortcut-mod=key[+...][,...]
        Specify the modifiers to use for scrcpy shortcuts.
        Possible keys are "lctrl", "rctrl", "lalt", "ralt", "lsuper" and "rsuper".
        A shortcut can consist in several keys, separated by '+'. Several shortcuts can be specified, separated by ','.
        For example, to use either LCtrl+LAlt or LSuper for scrcpy shortcuts, pass "lctrl+lalt,lsuper".
        Default is "lalt,lsuper" (left-Alt or left-Super).
    [...]
    Shortcuts:
    In the following list, MOD is the shortcut modifier. By default, it's (left) Alt or (left) Super, but it can be
    configured by --shortcut-mod (see above).
    
    MOD+f
        Switch fullscreen mode
    
    MOD+Left
        Rotate display left
    
    MOD+Right
        Rotate display right
    
    MOD+Shift+Left
    MOD+Shift+Right
        Flip display horizontally
    
    MOD+Shift+Up
    MOD+Shift+Down
        Flip display vertically
    
    MOD+g
        Resize window to 1:1 (pixel-perfect)
    
    MOD+w
    Double-click on black borders
        Resize window to remove black borders
    
    MOD+h
    Middle-click
        Click on HOME
    
    MOD+b
    MOD+Backspace
    Right-click (when screen is on)
        Click on BACK
    
    MOD+s
    4th-click
        Click on APP_SWITCH
    
    MOD+m
        Click on MENU
    
    MOD+Up
        Click on VOLUME_UP
    
    MOD+Down
        Click on VOLUME_DOWN
    
    MOD+p
        Click on POWER (turn screen on/off)
    
    Right-click (when screen is off)
        Power on
    
    MOD+o
        Turn device screen off (keep mirroring)
    
    MOD+Shift+o
        Turn device screen on
    
    MOD+r
        Rotate device screen
    
    MOD+n
    5th-click
        Expand notification panel
    
    MOD+Shift+n
        Collapse notification panel
    
    MOD+c
        Copy to clipboard (inject COPY keycode, Android >= 7 only)
    
    MOD+x
        Cut to clipboard (inject CUT keycode, Android >= 7 only)
    
    MOD+v
        Copy computer clipboard to device, then paste (inject PASTE keycode, Android >= 7 only)
    
    MOD+Shift+v
        Inject computer clipboard text as a sequence of key events
    
    MOD+i
        Enable/disable FPS counter (print frames/second in logs)
    
    Ctrl+click-and-move
        Pinch-to-zoom from the center of the screen
    
    Drag & drop APK file
        Install APK from computer
    
    Drag & drop non-APK file
        Push file to device (see --push-target)

title: Wireless disconnection when removing USB (oculus go)
body:
1. Connect the device to the same Wi-Fi as computer
2. Get device IP address: adb shell ip addr show wlan0
3. Enable adb over TCP/IP on device: adb tcpip 5555
4. Connect to device: adb connect DEVICE_IP:5555 (replace DEVICE_IP)
5. adb devices: shows two connections, one usb and one to the ip
5. Unplug device

At this point I'm expecting to be able to run;
7. Run scrcpy: scrcpy -s 192.168.1.185:5555

However, both devices are disconnected when pulling the usb cable out. 
As an alternate permutation: If I leave the usb connected and run step #7, scrcpy loads and then if I pull the usb - it disconnects.

Is there a better method for getting wireless connectivity working?
author: elodesignco

comments.body:
> However, both devices are disconnected when pulling the usb cable out.

I can't reproduce (with a Nexus 5, not an Oculus go). If I unplug the device, there is still the device connected over TCP.

Your device seems to restart/reconfigure adb when you unplug it.

I've been doing some more testing and after unplugging the USB, I can still use: adb connect DEVICE_IP:5555 and connect to the device. Can also ping the device also and get a response.

It appears to just disappear from the list of devices within ADB. I think it has something to do with MAC USB enumeration killing ADB, not the device itself.

```
[disconnect USB]

$ adb connect 192.168.1.185:5555
connected to 192.168.1.185:5555

$ ping 192.168.1.185
PING 192.168.1.185 (192.168.1.185): 56 data bytes
64 bytes from 192.168.1.185: icmp_seq=0 ttl=64 time=757.020 ms
64 bytes from 192.168.1.185: icmp_seq=1 ttl=64 time=210.854 ms
64 bytes from 192.168.1.185: icmp_seq=2 ttl=64 time=768.758 ms

$ scrcpy
```
